    Development of Multifunctional Pyrimidinylthiourea Derivatives as Potential Anti-Alzheimer Agents

    • Xiaokang Li†
      • , 
    • Huan Wang‡
      • , 
    • Zhengyu Lu†
      • , 
    • Xinyu Zheng†
      • , 
    • Wei Ni†
      • , 
    • Jin Zhu†
      • , 
    • Yan Fu‡
      • , 
    • Fulin Lian§
      • , 
    • Naixia Zhang§
      • , 
    • Jian Li*†
      • , 
    • Haiyan Zhang*‡
      • , and 
    • Fei Mao*†
    View Author Information
    † Shanghai Key Laboratory of New Drug Design, School of Pharmacy, East China University of Science and Technology, 130 Mei Long Road, Shanghai 200237, China
    ‡ CAS Key Laboratory of Receptor Research, Shanghai Institute of Materia Medica, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 555 Zu Chong Zhi Road, Shanghai 201203, China
    § Shanghai Institute of Materia Medica, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 555 Zu Chong Zhi Road, Shanghai 201203, China

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Starting from a screening-hit compound, via structure modifications and optimizations, a series of nonfused and nonassembly pyrimidinylthiourea derivatives (2–5) was designed, synthesized, and evaluated as novel multifunctional agents against Alzheimer’s disease. Biological activity results demonstrated that compounds 5r and 5t exhibited potent inhibition and excellent selectivity toward acetylcholinesterase (AChE, 5r, IC50 = 0.204 μM, SI > 196; 5t, IC50 = 0.067 μM, SI > 597), specific metal-chelating ability, significant antioxidant effects, modulation of metal-induced Aβ aggregation, inhibition of ROS production by copper redox cycle, low cytotoxicity, and moderate neuroprotection to human neuroblastoma SH-SY5Y cells. Moreover, compound 5r displayed appropriate blood–brain barrier (BBB) permeability both in vitro and in vivo and could improve memory and cognitive function of scopolamine-induced amnesia mice. The multifunctional profiles of 5r and its effectivity in AD mice highlight these structurally distinct pyrimidinylthiourea derivatives as prospective prototypes in the research of innovative multifunctional drugs for Alzheimer’s disease.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a chronic, fatal, and neurodegenerative disease in the brain; its mechanism has not been fully elucidated due to complex etiology. As the most common form of dementia and the leading cause of death among the elderly, approximately 44 million patients suffer from AD, and the number is increasing annually.(1, 2) Commercial drugs for AD treatment are unable to meet the market demand. The failure of several candidates based on new targets in clinical trials actuated new strategies for drug development.(3) Thus, multitarget-directed ligands (MTDLs), aiming to simultaneously target multiple pathological processes involved in the neurodegenerative cascade, were developed as a therapeutic approach.(4-13)
    Acetylcholine (ACh), a major neurotransmitter widely existing in the brain, plays an important role in learning, memory, cognition, and maintaining consciousness.(14, 15) Studies indicated that 90% of cholinergic neurons were damaged in the brain of AD patients, and the associated cholinergic neurotransmitter in the cerebral cortex and hippocampus decreased dramatically.(16-18) Thus, remedying the physiological ACh levels has been considered a feasible therapy for AD.(14, 19) The major pathway of ACh activity termination is hydrolysis by AChE. Therefore, inhibitors of AChE appear to be a beneficial approach to repair the cholinergic transmission pathway.(20) Currently, the therapeutic options for AD treatment are limited to four AChE inhibitors (AChEIs),(21) namely, donepezil, rivastigmine, galantamine, and huperzine A (Hup A, approved by CFDA) and one N-methyl-d-aspartic acid (NMDA) receptor antagonist, memantine.(22)
    An increasing body of evidence suggests that the pathogenesis of AD is an extremely complex interconnected network.(23-25) In addition to the low level of the neurotransmitter ACh, this complex multisystem disease features multiple pathological hallmarks, including abnormal accumulation and deposition of β amyloid protein (Aβ), dysregulation of biometals, oxidative stress, and neuroinflammation of the CNS (central nervous system).(23, 25, 26) The high levels and dysregulation of biometal ions, such as Cu2+, Zn2+, and Fe2+, are closely implicated in the pathogenesis of AD. These metal ions (especially Cu2+ and Zn2+) bind to Aβ peptides and influence the Aβ aggregation pathway, leading to the generation of toxic Aβ oligomers.(25-27) Moreover, redox-active metal ions, Cu(I/II) and Fe(II/III), which are associated with Aβ, were demonstrated to produce reactive oxygen species (ROS) under physiological conditions through Fenton-like reactions. The overproduction of ROS leads to oxidative stress and eventually neuronal death in AD patients.(23, 27-30) Therefore, biometal chelators endowed with the ability to modulate metal–Aβ interactions, as well as the metal distribution in the brain, have been considered as a potential therapeutic approach for AD. In addition, neurotoxic ROS and oxidative damage of neuronal cells are generally associated with AD, so compounds with antioxidant activities may be beneficial for the treatment of AD.(31, 32)
    Many researchers have devoted their efforts to the development of MTDLs as a hopeful approach to combat the multifactorial nature of AD. Typically, two or three bioactive scaffolds with beneficial anti-AD properties were assembled or fused to obtain new chemical entities, which possessed multiple abilities due to the functional superposition of each constituent fragment and additional synergetic activities (Table S1, Supporting Information). For example, tacrine–8-hydroxyquinoline hybrid,(33) 6-chlorotacrine–metal–Aβ modulator hybrid,(34) donepezil–8-hydroxyquinoline–propargylamine hybrid,(35) tacrine–flavonoid hybrid,(36) HLA20A and M30D(37) were all obtained by assembling AChEIs and metal chelator fragments (Figure 1). The hybrid strategies have had success in the field of MTLDs but possess an apparent design flaw: excessive dependence on the structure of limited known bioactive compounds, such as tacrine, donepezil, clioquinol, rhein, melatonin, resveratrol, and coumarin (Table S1). Therefore, to broaden the research extent of multifunctional anti-AD drugs, the discovery of nonfused and nonassembly lead compounds with multiple anti-AD properties is extremely urgent.
    Toward this end, we have identified a series of nonfused and nonassembly multifunctional pyrimidinylthiourea derivatives as prospective anti-AD agents. Among them, the aminomethylimidazole-containing pyrimidinylthiourea derivatives 5l–x showed potent inhibition and excellent selectivity toward AChE, as well as mild antioxidant properties. Integrally considering the abilities of metal-chelating, modulating metal-induced Aβ aggregation, free radical scavenging, low cytotoxicity, and moderate neuroprotective effect, compounds 5r and 5t were identified as the prototype of potential multifunctional anti-Alzheimer agents. Compound 5r also showed positive results in an AD mice cognitive ability test, demonstrating that our pyrimidinylthiourea derivatives possess development potential as prospective anti-AD agents.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Discovery of Hit Compound 1

    Because several AChEIs have successfully been approved to be marketed as drugs and have made prominent contributions to the symptomatic improvement of AD patients,(20, 21) AChE inhibitory ability should be first considered in the process of searching for new multifunctional anti-AD scaffolds. An in-house library with 630 small molecular compounds (MW < 300) was screened using the AChE inhibition assay. A “cocktail” of tactics was imitated to simplify this process. The detailed steps are as follows. First, 630 compounds were screened through the AChE inhibition assay in 96-well plates with 10 compounds per well. Then, each constituent in positive wells was screened again using the same method but with one compound per well. Finally, the positive wells contained compounds with potential AChE inhibitory activity. Pyrimidine derivative 1 was one of the discovered compounds and exhibited some AChE inhibitory activity (inhibition rate: 32.15% at 40 μM). Compound 1 was designated as a hit compound because a similar disubstituted pyrimidine scaffold has appeared in potential anti-AD agents, such as AChEI, Aβ-aggregation inhibitors, and receptor for advanced glycation end products (RAGE) inhibitors,(38-41) and also has good synthetic accessibility.

    Design and Synthesis

    First, the ethylamino group of hit 1 was replaced by ethyoxyl, n-propyl, benzylamino, amino, acetylamino, and different substituted thiourea moieties to produce target compounds 2a–o. As depicted in Scheme 1, reaction of pyrazole and commercially available 4,6-dichloropyrimidine or 4-amino-6-chloropyrimidine gave the key intermediate 6 and compound 2d, respectively. Nucleophilic substitution of the C-2 chlorine of intermediate 6 provided target compounds 2a–c. Target compound 2e was obtained by acetylation of 2d with acetyl chloride in the presence of Et3N. The reaction of 2d with ethyl isocyanate and different substituted isothiocyanates in the presence of NaH provided the target compounds 2f and 2g–o.
    Ethylthiourea analogue 2g was treated as lead compound for its significantly increased activity (Table 1). The ethylthiourea moiety was demonstrated as indispensable pharmacophore for AChE inhibitory activity and played important role in generating metal chelation(42) and antioxidant properties.(43-45) The pyrazolyl group of compound 2g was regarded as a modification site and was replaced by various aza-aromatics, such as pyrrolyl (3a), imidazolyl (3b), 1,2,3-triazolyl (3c), 1,2,4-triazolyl (3d), benzo[d]imidazolyl (3e), and different alicyclic amino groups, such as pyrrolidinyl (3f), morpholino (3g), 4-methylpiperazinyl (3h), benzylamino (3i) (Scheme 2). Commercially available 4-amino-6-chloropyrimidine was reacted with aza-aromatic compounds or alicyclic amines to provide intermediates 7a–i, followed by treatment with ethyl isothiocyanate to afford target compounds 3a–i.
    Table 1. Structures and rAChE Inhibitory Activities of Compounds 1 and 2a–o
    compdRinhibition of rAChE, [I] = 40 μMIC50 ± SD (μM)a
    1CH3CH2NH32.15–
    2aCH3CH2O11.76–
    2bCH3CH2CH29.88–
    2cPhCH2NH10.75–
    2dNH218.91–
    2eCH3CONH5.09–
    2fCH3CH2NHCONH22.14–
    2gCH3CH2NHCSNH77.268.14 ± 0.40
    2hCH3NHCSNH46.00–
    2iCH3CH2CH2NHCSNH64.0122.00 ± 1.20
    2j(CH3)2CHNHCSNH36.22–
    2kCH3CH2CH2CH2NHCSNH66.5823.40 ± 0.90
    2l(CH3)3CNHCSNH11.30–
    2mcyclohexyl-NHCSNH11.21–
    2nPhCH2NHCSNH17.29–
    2o3-Cl-C6H4NHCSNH0.00–
    a

    Results are expressed as the mean of at least three experiments. “–” indicates no test.

    Imidazolyl analogue 3b showed improved potency (Table 2) and had sufficient modifiable sites. The imidazolyl moiety (3b) remained in the following structure modification. The 4,6-disubstituted pyrimidine core was treated as the next replacement part. Then, target compounds 4a–e were designed and obtained by the reaction of intermediates 8a–e (synthetic details, see Supporting Information) with ethyl isothiocyanate in the presence of NaH (Scheme 3).
    Table 2. Structures and rAChE Inhibitory Activities of Compounds 3a–i
    Table a

    Results are expressed as the mean of at least three experiments.

    Having maintained the integrity of compound 3b (Table 3), a series of target compounds 5a–k with diverse substituents at C-2 or C-4 of the imidazole ring were designed and synthesized to improve the biological activities and to expand the SAR studies (Scheme 4). Nucleophilic substitution of 4-amino-6-chloropyrimidine with substituted imidazole derivatives afforded intermediates 9a–j, which were further reacted with ethyl isothiocyanate in the presence of NaH to obtain compounds 5a–j. Reduction of 5i with NaBH4 gave compound 5k.
    Table 3. Structures and rAChE Inhibitory Activities of Compounds 4a–e
    Table a

    Results are expressed as the mean of at least three experiments.

    Finally, for the potent inhibitory activity of compound 5i against AChE, a series of compounds 5l–x, possessing diverse aminomethyl groups on the C-4 position of the imidazole ring, were designed and synthesized (Scheme 4). Compounds 5l–x were prepared by reductive amination of compound 5i with diverse aliphatic amines in the presence of NaBH3(CN).
    In total, 53 derivatives (i.e., 2a–o, 3a–i, 4a–4e, and 5a–x) were designed and synthesized, their chemical structures are shown in Tables 1–4, and details of the synthetic procedures and structural characterization are described in the Experimental Section.
    Table 4. Structures, rAChE, and rBuChE Inhibitory Activities, Selectivity Index for rAChE, and Oxygen Radical Absorbance Capacity (ORAC, Trolox Equivalents) of Compounds 5a–x
    Table a

    Results are expressed as the mean of at least three experiments. “–“ indicates no test.

    Table b

    Selectivity index for AChE is defined as IC50(rBuChE)/IC50(rAChE).

    Table c

    The mean ± SD of three independent experiments. Data are expressed as μmol of Trolox equivalent/μmol of tested compounds.

    Cholinesterase (ChE) Inhibitory Activity

    To determine the therapeutic potential of these pyrimidine derivatives for the treatment of AD, compounds 2a–o, 3a–i, 4a–4e, and 5a–x were assayed against rat AChE (rAChE) by the modified method of Ellman et al.,(46) using huperzine A (Hup A) as reference. The experimental results were presented as IC50 (μM) or, for poorly active compounds, as the percentage of inhibition at 40 μM. The tested compounds displayed poor to excellent rAChE inhibitory activity (Tables 1–4). Compounds 5i, 5l–m, 5o–x with good rAChE inhibition were further tested for their inhibitory activities against rat butyrylcholinesterase (rBuChE) using the same method, and the activity results and selectivity indexes (SI) are summarized in Table 4.
    Examples of variation in the initial ethylamino group of hit 1 gave encouraging results (Table 1). Compound 2g, with the ethylamino group replaced by an ethylthiourea group, exhibited good inhibitory activity, with an IC50 of 8.14 μM. However, replacement of the ethylthiourea group with a similar ethylurea group was not tolerated (2g vs 2f). Introduction of either larger (2i–o) or smaller (2h) substituents on the N-3 atom decreased the potency. This observation indicates that steric hindrance of the N-3 substituent of thiourea may play an important role in the binding modes of compounds to AChE.
    As shown in Table 2, changing pyrazolyl into various types of aza-aromatics or alicyclic amino groups remarkably affected the AChE inhibitory activities. Generally, alicyclic amino substituents (3f–i) were not beneficial, while the introduction of aza-aromatic substituents (3b–e), except pyrrolyl (3a), was favorable. Among them, compounds 3b and 3d were relatively potent, with IC50 values of 1.59 μM and 1.05 μM, respectively. In the studied set of central cores (Table 3), changing the position of the N atom in the ring (4c,d) and introducing substituents on the ring (4a,b and 4e) were not tolerated, leading to an obvious decline in potency.
    The data in Table 4 show that introduction alkyl groups on the C-2 position of the imidazole ring (5a,b) was not beneficial. Compared with C-2 methyl derivative 5a, C-4 methyl derivative 5c showed relatively increased potency, so the C-4 position was considered the preferable modification site. Fortunately, the following C-4-substituted derivatives 5d–k exhibited more increased activities than prototype 3b. The two most effective inhibitors, 5h (IC50 = 0.170 μM) and 5i (IC50 = 0.166 μM), were nearly 10-fold more potent than 3b. Compounds 5l–x possessed aminomethyl moieties on the C-4 position of the imidazole ring and exhibited good potency. Among them, compound 5t was the most potent, with an IC50 value of 0.067 μM, more potent than the approved drug Hup A (0.082 μM).
    As presented in Table 4, compounds 5i, 5l–m, 5o–x displayed poor to micromolar potency against rBuChE and excellent selectivity toward rAChE. Compound 5v was the strongest rBuChE inhibitor and displayed the lowest SI value of 59. The most potent compound, 5t, exhibited weak BuChE inhibitory activity, indicating 5t was an outstanding selective AChE inhibitor over BuChE.

    SAR Studies

    On the basis of hit 1, the key transitionary compounds of structural optimization are illustrated in Figure 2. The SAR studies of the 53 derivatives provided important insight into the essential structural requirements for effective AChE inhibition. An analysis of the data shown in Tables 1–4 reveals noteworthy observations of the SARs for compounds 2a–o, 3a–i, 4a–e, and 5a–x: (1) the thiourea moiety is indispensable pharmacophore for AChE inhibitory activity; replacement of thiourea moiety with urea or other groups decreases the activity dramatically (2g vs 1, 2f, 2a–e). There is an extremely rigid requirement for the steric hindrance of the N-3 substituents of thiourea; an ethyl group (2g) is optimal, and smaller (2h) or bigger (2i–o) substituents result in obvious loss of potency. (2) Considering the improved potency and sufficient modifiable sites, the imidazole ring is the most suitable substituent at the C-6 position of the pyrimidine ring (3b vs 2g, 3a, 3c, 3e–i; 3b vs 3d). (3) The 4,6-disubstituted pyrimidine core is critical for AChE inhibition; changing the N atom position or introduction other substituents led to remarkable decline of inhibitory activity (3b vs 4a–e), and (4) the C-4 position on imidazole ring was a promising substituted site (5c vs 5a; 5d–k vs 3b); compounds 5l–x with protonatable aminomethyl moieties are potent AChE inhibitors. The N-monosubstituted aminomethyl derivatives 5l–o display relatively weak inhibitory potency. For N-disubstituted aminomethyl derivatives, the potencies increase in the order of diethylaminomethyl > dimethylaminomethyl > benzyl(methyl)aminomethyl > dipropylaminomethyl (5q > 5p > 5s > 5r); for the cyclic aminomethyl derivatives, the potencies decrease following the augmentation of the cycle size: pyrrolidinylmethyl > piperidinylmethyl > azepanylmethyl (5t > 5u > 5v). In brief, the SARs are highly explicit. Analogue 5t represented the most robust combination, leading to 121-fold potency improvement compared to the lead compound 2g.

    Free Oxygen Radical Scavenging Ability

    To evaluate the antioxidant activities of compounds 5i, 5l–m, 5o–x, the oxygen radical absorbance capacity assay (ORAC-FL) was performed using fluorescein as the fluorescent probe and AAPH (2,2′-azobis-(amidinopropane)dihydrochloride) as the peroxyl radical inducer.(47, 48) Trolox, a vitamin E analogue, was used as a standard. CQ was tested as reference, and compound 5y (without thiourea fragment, Supporting Information) was measured as a negative control. The results (Table 4) indicated that all the tested compounds exhibited mild antioxidant ability with ORAC values of 1.17–1.48, except compound 5i, which featured an aldehyde group on the imidazole ring (0.31). Compound 5w displayed the highest activity, with an ORAC-FL value of 1.48. Moreover, the thiourea fragment played a crucial role in scavenging ROS (5t vs 5y).

    Metal Binding Properties of 5r and 5t

    A UV–vis spectroscopy assay was performed to evaluate the ability of compounds 5r and 5t to chelate biometals, such as Cu2+, Fe2+, and Zn2+. The results showed that when CuCl2 was added to the solutions of 5r and 5t, the maximum absorption both decreased dramatically at 290 nm, demonstrating the formation of 5r–Cu2+ and 5t–Cu2+ complexes (Figure 3A, Figure 3B). There were only vague optical shift and maximum absorption fluctuation when FeSO4, FeCl3, and ZnCl2 were added, indicating 5r and 5t had poor chelation abilities to Fe2+, Fe3+, and Zn2+. Compound 5t was selected to test its binding property to other biological relevant metals, such as Mg2+, Ca2+, Mn2+, Ni2+, Co2+ and exhibited very weak chelation ability (Figure S2, Supporting Information). A competition experiment was performed to verify the metal ion selectivity of 5t, the results demonstrated that Cu2+ could competitively bind to 5t (Figure S3, Supporting Information). Compound 5y, without thiourea fragment, was tested as negative control to determine the role of thiourea moiety played in the chelating experiment. As expected, the absorption curve exhibited a slight shift when CuCl2, FeSO4, FeCl3, and ZnCl2 were added (Figure 3C). The above results proved that target compound 5t could selectively chelate Cu2+, and this property was determined by the thiourea fragment. Clioquinol (CQ) was selected as control (Figure 3D).

    Dot Blot Assay and TEM Assay

    The modulation of metal-induced Aβ aggregation by compounds 5r and 5t was studied through a dot blot assay,(49, 50) and a transmission electron microscopy (TEM)(4, 13) assay was then performed to examine the morphological changes of Aβ species. In the dot blot assay, samples were probed by A11 antibody to determine oligomeric Aβ, and total Aβ was detected by 6E10 as the loading control. A representative scan graph and a statistical histogram are presented in Figure 4A; the gray density of the spots is proportional to the Aβ oligomerization level. After a 24 h incubation, Aβ aggregated extremely and compounds 5r and 5t showed no effect on Aβ self-aggregation. Epigallocatechin gallate (EGCG) was tested as positive control. To verify this result, we performed a thioflavine T (ThT) fluorescence assay and achieved similar estimates (Figure S4, Supporting Information). Most importantly, the dot blot assay clearly showed that Cu2+ could accelerate Aβ aggregation, and this process was significantly regulated by compounds 5r and 5t.
    Further visual morphological changes of the Aβ samples were observed by TEM (Figure 4B). The TEM images demonstrated that the Cu2+-treated sample of fresh Aβ produced more fibrils than the untreated sample (Figure 4B, sequences 2 and 3). Aβ aggregates obviously decreased, and fewer Aβ fibrils were detected when compounds 5r and 5t and CQ were incubated with the sample (Figure 4B, sequences 4, 5, and 6). These TEM results were consistent with the results of the dot blot assay and jointly demonstrated that compounds 5r and 5t can indeed modulate Cu2+-induced Aβ aggregation.

    Inhibition of ROS Produced by Copper Redox Cycling

    Increased generation of ROS is a significant pathological feature of AD patients, and clinical evidence indicated that redox-active metal ions were closely involved in the high oxidative stress caused by ROS.(31, 32) Moreover, Aβ could spontaneously produce ROS in the presence of trace amounts of metals, especially copper.(51-54) Considering their biological activities as metal chelators, the abilities of compounds 5r and 5t to halt Cu(II)-related redox under aerobic conditions were evaluated, utilizing the model of the Cu-ascorbate redox system described by Faller and co-workers(55) (Figure 5A). Hydroxyl radicals (OH·), produced by copper redox cycling in the presence of ascorbate, were measured by coincubation with coumarin-3-carboxylic acid (CCA), which generated fluorescent 7-hydroxy-CCA with the oxidation of OH·. As shown in Figure 5B, the OH· in the copper-ascorbate system increased steadily with time and reached a plateau at approximately 800 s. However, this process was entirely inhibited when compounds 5r and 5t were coincubated with the Cu-ascorbate system, indicating that the ligands were capable of halting copper redox cycling by generating a redox-inactive complex.(56) The documented metal chelator ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) was measured as a control.

    MTT Assay

    To investigate the safety of the pyrimidinylthiourea derivatives, the cytotoxicity of compounds 5r and 5t on the human neuroblastoma cell line SH-SY5Y was studied using a 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide (MTT) assay to determine cell death. Marketed anti-AD drugs Hup A and donepezil (Don) were tested as references. As depicted in Figure 6A, compounds 5r and 5t, like Hup A and Don, exhibited no cytotoxicity at concentrations of 10 μM and 30 μM after incubation for 24 h. After increasing the concentration to a relatively high level of 100 μM, 5r, 5t, and Don decreased the cell viability (p < 0.01, p < 0.01, and p < 0.001, respectively), while Hup A had no obvious influence on cell viability. Therefore, compounds 5r and 5t were proved to have low cytotoxicity.
    Next, to determine whether compounds 5r and 5t can protect neuronal cells from toxic Aβ species, cell viability experiments were conducted using the same cell line. As shown in Figure 6B, incubation of SH-SY5Y cells with Aβ in the presence of Cu2+ caused significant toxicity; its cell viability was approximately 39% lower than the vehicle group (P < 0.001) and 11% lower than the Aβ alone group (P < 0.001). Compounds 5r and 5t could protect the human neuronal SH-SY5Y cells from Cu2+-induced Aβ aggregate toxicity, leading to significant increase in cell viability compared with the Aβ + Cu2+ group (P < 0.001 and P < 0.001). CQ was tested as positive control. Moreover, compounds 5r and 5t could not interact with Aβ directly to restrain the cytotoxicity of Aβ aggregates. These results are highly consistent with the results from the dot blot assay. Compounds 5r and 5t in the presence of Cu2+ or Cu2+ alone did not influence the SH-SY5Y cell viability in the tested concentrations.

    In Vitro Blood–Brain Barrier Permeation Assay and Druglikeness Evaluation

    Blood–brain barrier (BBB) permeability is the first requirement for developing anti-AD drugs. The parallel artificial membrane permeation assay (PAMPA)(13, 57) was used to predict passive BBB permeation of optimized compounds 5p–x. From the results presented in Table 5, it can be observed that the most potent AChE inhibitor, compound 5t, exhibited poor BBB permeation (CNS−). Compounds 5r,s and 5u,v, which possess compensatory hydrophobic substituents on the nitrogen atom of the C-4 aminomethyl of the imidazole ring, have Pe values above the threshold for good BBB permeation (CNS+), indicating they could cross the BBB. Among them, compounds 5r,s exhibited comparatively better BBB permeability than 5u,v.
    Table 5. Permeability Results (Pe, 10–6 cm s–1) from the PAMPA-BBB Assay for Compounds 5p–x and Their Prediction of BBB Penetration
    compdPe (10–6 cm s–1)apredictionb
    5p3.0 ± 0.2CNS±
    5q1.0 ± 0.35CNS–
    5r7.5 ± 0.5CNS+
    5s8.8 ± 0.05CNS+
    5t1.15 ± 0.44CNS–
    5u5.0 ± 0.2CNS+
    5v5.3 ± 0.2CNS+
    5w0.35 ± 0.03CNS–
    5x1.95 ± 0.08CNS±
    desipramine16.6 ± 1.20CNS+
    a

    Values are expressed as the mean ± SD of at least three independent experiments.

    b

    Compounds with permeabilities Pe > 4.7 × 10–6 cm s–1 could cross the BBB by passive diffusion (CNS+). Compounds with Pe < 1.8 × 10–6 cm s–1 could not cross the BBB (CNS−), and compounds with 1.8 × 10–6 cm s–1 < Pe < 4.7 × 10–6 cm s–1 show uncertain BBB permeation (CNS±).

    To determine the potential druggability of compounds 5r–s, their druglike physicochemical properties were evaluated.(58) As shown in Table 6, compounds 5r,s both obey the Lipinski’s rule of five(59, 60) and fulfill the restrictions of topological polar surface area (tPSA)(61) and melting point (MP)(62) for CNS drugs. Compound 5r shows a relatively high value of clogP (calculated logarithm of the octanol–water partition coefficient),(63) and the corresponding hydrochloride 5r·HCl displays better water solubility than 5s·HCl. Therefore, compound 5r·HCl was selected to conduct further animal cognitive ability experiments.
    Table 6. Druglike Physicochemical Properties of Compounds 5r–ta
    compdMWHBAHBDclogPtPSAbmp (°C)water solubility (mg/mL)water solubility of hydrochloride (mg/mL)
    5t331.44720.7770.90179–1800.3419.5
    5r361.51722.2670.90158–1610.0583.38
    5s381.50721.9170.90153–1550.0582.74
    rules<450c<10d<5d<5d<90e60–220f  
    a

    MW: molecular weight. HBA: hydrogen-bond acceptor atoms. HBD: hydrogen-bond donor atoms. clogP: calculated logarithm of the octanol–water partition coefficient. tPSA: topological polar surface area. MP: melting point.

    b

    http://www.molinspiration.com/cgi-bin/properties.

    c

    See ref 64.

    d

    Lipinski’s rules.

    e

    See ref 62.

    f

    See ref 63.

    Cognitive Improvement in Mice Model of AD

    The effects of compounds 5r·HCl and 5t·HCl on cognitive improvement were assessed in a scopolamine (Scop)-induced amnesia animal model using a passageway water maze; Hup A at 0.1 mg/kg was used as a positive control. Scop can block the cholinergic pathway by antagonizing the muscarinic receptor,(64) which provides a typical AD model to explore the role of the cholinergic system in cognition and to evaluate anticholinergic drug candidates preclinically.(65) In the experiment, all mice received 2 training sessions daily for 4 days before a cognitive ability test; then, the trained mice were randomly allocated into 5 groups: control (Con), Scop, Scop + 5t·HCl, Scop + 5r·HCl, and Scop + Hup A. As shown in Figure 7, the Scop group exhibited longer escape latency and more frequent error than the Con group (saline-injected group). Compound 5r·HCl, administered to mice by oral gavage at a dose of 200 mg/kg, rescued the escape latency and reduced the number of errors induced by scopolamine. The effectivity of 5r·HCl for symptom improvement in AD mice model identifies it as a potential lead anti-AD agent, especially for the treatment of cholinergic deficiency in the early stages of the disease.

    Measuring 5r in Plasma and Brain Samples

    Liquid chromatography tandem mass spectroscopy (LC–MS/MS) was used to identify and quantify the plasma and brain (cortex, hippocampus) levels of compound 5r after oral administration(66, 67) (5r·HCl at 200 mg/kg). As shown in Table 7, compound 5r was detected in the brain tissues (cortex, 296.3 ng/g; hippocampus, 579.1 ng/g) and plasma (1738.9 ng/g). The log BB values were used to evaluate BBB permeability; two vital brain areas showed the log BB values of −0.85 (cortex) and −0.49 (hippocampus), which were within the established threshold that defines a compound as crossing the BBB (log BB ≥ −1).(68) Therefore, compound 5r crosses the blood–brain barrier.
    Table 7. 5r Concentrations in Plasma, Cortex, and Hippocampus and log BB Values 1 h after Oral Administration to Micea
    sampleplasma (ng/mL)Ctx (ng/g)Hipp (ng/g)log BB (Ctx)log BB (Hipp)
    N = 31738.9 ± 249.7296.3 ± 232.7579.1 ± 183.0–0.85 ± 0.38–0.49 ± 0.19
    a

    Ctx, cortex; Hipp, hippocampus; Br, brain. Values are expressed as the mean ± SD of three independent experiments. BB is the ratio of the brain tissue to plasma concentration.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    By understanding the heterogeneity and the multifactorial nature of the disease, a single chemical entity against multiple disease-relevant targets might offer a potential approach to the treatment of AD. Given that most of the drugs marketed for AD are cholinergic agents, AChE inhibitory activity was recognized as a prospective focus point to guide MTDL design strategy. The deficiency of novel bioactive scaffolds largely hindered the development of multifunctional anti-AD agents, especially because many researchers continue to concentrate on the strategy of fusing or assembling pharmacophores of limited known bioactive entities. Therefore, it is urgent to search for a new scaffold as the hit compound for multifunctional anti-AD agent design.
    Through an in vitro HTS campaign, hit 1, with some AChE inhibitory activity, was screened out. Then, a series of pyrimidinylthiourea derivatives was rationally designed, synthesized, and assayed. The SAR studies revealed that the thiourea fragment acted as an indispensable pharmacophore for AChE inhibitory activity and played a crucial role in generating metal-chelating and antioxidant properties. Compounds 5r and 5t exhibited multiple anti-AD properties and showed low cytotoxicity and moderate neuroprotection to human neuroblastoma SH-SY5Y cells. By changing the R3, R4 substituents (Scheme 4) on the nitrogen atom of the C-4 aminomethyl on the imidazole ring, the water solubility, lipophilicity, and BBB permeability could be modified. Compound 5r exerted appropriate BBB permeation and fulfilled druglike rules. Its hydrochloride was used to conduct the animal cognitive ability experiment and showed a remarkable improvement of memory and cognitive function in a Scop-induced amnesia animal model.
    In conclusion, this work clearly validates the nonfused and nonassembly multifunctional ligands design strategy and discovers a series of novel pyrimidinylthiourea derivatives with multiple anti-AD profiles. These compounds can be considered as potential prototypes to guide the future research of innovative multifunctional drugs for Alzheimer’s disease.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Chemistry. General Method

    Reagents and solvents were purchased from Adamas-beta, J&K, Energy Chemical, Target Molecule, TCI, Alfa Aesar, and Acros and were used without further purification. Analytical thin-layer chromatography (TLC) was performed using HSGF 254 (150–200 μm thickness; Yantai Huiyou Co., China), and spots were visualized with UV light. Yields were not optimized. Melting points were measured in capillary tubes on a SGW X-4 melting point apparatus without correction. Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy was performed on a Bruker AMX-400 NMR (IS as TMS). Chemical shifts were reported in parts per million (ppm, δ) downfield from tetramethylsilane. Proton coupling patterns were described as singlet (s), doublet (d), triplet (t), quartet (q), multiplet (m), and broad (br). High-resolution mass spectra (HRMS) were obtained by electric ionization (EI) and electrospray ionization (ESI) using a Waters GCT Premie and Waters LCT. HPLC data analysis of compounds 2–5 was performed on an Agilent 1100 with a quaternary pump and diode array detector (DAD). The peak purity was verified by UV spectra. All analogs were confirmed to be ≥95% pure (Table S2, Supporting Information).

    N-Ethyl-6-(1H-pyrazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-amine (1)

    A mixture of 6 (390 mg, 2 mmol), ethylamine (4 mmol), and Cs2CO3 (1.30 g, 4 mmol) was stirred in DMF (10 mL) at 40–50 °C overnight. Water (60 mL) was added. The mixture was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 60 mL). The organic layer was separated and dried over Na2SO4. Removal of the solvents produced a residue which was purified using column chromatography, eluted with a mixture of EtOAc/petroleum ether (1:3, v/v), to afford compound 1 as yellow solid. 58% yield. Mp 119–121 °C. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.53 (d, J = 2.6 Hz, 1H), 8.40 (s, 1H), 7.75 (d, J = 0.9 Hz, 1H), 7.26 (s, 1H), 6.91 (s, 1H), 6.46 (dd, J = 2.6, 1.7 Hz, 1H), 5.38 (s, 1H), 3.52–3.31 (m, 2H), 1.34–1.22 (m, 3H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C9H11N5 (M+) 189.1014, found 189.1015.

    4-Ethoxy-6-(1H-pyrazol-1-yl)pyrimidine (2a)

    To a solution of NaH (60% dispersion in mineral oil, 240 mg, 6 mmol) in stirred anhydrous DMF (10 mL) were added anhydrous EtOH (263 μL, 4.5 mmol) and intermediate 6 (542 mg, 3 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 4 h. Water (50 mL) was added and the mixture was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 60 mL). The organic layer was separated and dried over Na2SO4. Removal of the solvents produced a residue which was purified using column chromatography, eluted with a mixture of EtOAc/petroleum ether (1:50, v/v), to afford 2a (280 mg, 49%) as a brown oil. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.60 (d, J = 0.5 Hz, 1H), 8.57–8.50 (m, 1H), 7.76 (d, J = 1.0 Hz, 1H), 7.25 (d, J = 0.9 Hz, 1H), 6.48 (dd, J = 2.6, 1.7 Hz, 1H), 4.47 (q, J = 7.1 Hz, 2H), 1.43 (t, J = 7.1 Hz, 3H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C9H10N4O (M+) 190.0855, found 190.0854.

    4-Propyl-6-(1H-pyrazol-1-yl)pyrimidine (2b)

    A mixture of 6 (90 mg, 0.5 mmol) and ferrous acetylacetonate (25.4 mg, 0.1 mmol) in anhydrous THF were stirred at −30 °C for 10 min, with protection of N2. Then n-propylmagnesium bromide (2 M in THF, 0.5 mL, 1 mmol) was added by syringe. Saturated NH4Cl aqueous solution was added 1 h later. The mixture was extracted with EtOAc. The organic layer was separated and dried over Na2SO4. Removal of the solvents produced a residue which was purified using column chromatography, eluted with a mixture of EtOAc/petroleum ether (1:15, v/v), to afford 2b as a brown oil. 15% yield. 1H NMR (400 MHz, acetone-d6) δ 8.90 (s, 1H), 8.65 (d, J = 2.6 Hz, 1H), 7.85 (s, 1H), 7.82 (s, 1H), 6.60 (s, 1H), 2.82 (t, J = 14.1, 5.9 Hz, 2H), 1.90–1.73 (m, 2H), 0.99 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 3H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C10H12N4 (M+) 188.1062, found 188.1063.

    N-Benzyl-6-(1H-pyrazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-amine (2c)

    A mixture of 6 (390 mg, 2 mmol), benzylamine (4 mmol), and Cs2CO3 (1.30 g, 4 mmol) was stirred in DMF (10 mL) at 40–50 °C overnight. Water (60 mL) was added. The mixture was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 60 mL). The organic layer was separated and dried over Na2SO4. Removal of the solvents produced a residue which was purified using column chromatography, eluted with a mixture of EtOAc/petroleum ether (1:3, v/v), to afford 2c as yellow solid. 60% yield. Mp 167–170 °C. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.54 (d, J = 2.5 Hz, 1H), 8.39 (s, 1H), 8.25 (s, 1H), 7.84 (s, 1H), 7.38–7.31 (m, 4H), 7.30–7.19 (m, 1H), 7.02 (s, 1H), 6.56 (s, 1H), 4.62 (s, 2H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C14H13N5 (M+) 251.1171, found 251.1170.

    6-(1H-Pyrazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-amine (2d)

    A mixture of pyrazole (0.75 g, 10 mmol), 4-amino-6-chloropyrimidine (1.30 g, 10 mmol), and Cs2CO3 (3.91 g, 12 mmol) was stirred in DMF (20 mL) for 12 h at 120 °C. Water (100 mL) was added. The mixture was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 60 mL). The organic layer was separated and dried over Na2SO4. Removal of the solvents produced a residue which was purified using column chromatography, eluted with a mixture of EtOAc/petroleum ether (1:1, v/v), to afford 2d (835 mg, 52%) as a yellow solid. Mp 235–237 °C. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.48–8.43 (m, 1H), 8.33 (d, J = 0.8 Hz, 1H), 7.82 (t, J = 1.4 Hz, 1H), 7.20 (s, 2H), 7.15–7.08 (m, 1H), 6.57 (d, J = 1.0 Hz, 1H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C7H7N5 (M+) 161.0701, found 161.0702.

    N-(6-(1H-Pyrazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl)acetamide (2e)

    To a solution of 2d (161 mg, 1 mmol) and Et3N (278 μL, 2 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (20 mL) stirred in ice bath was added AcCl (142 μL, 2 mmol) dropwise. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. Remove the precipitate by filtration, and evaporate the solvent to dryness under reduced pressure. The residue was purified on a silica gel column using mixtures of EtOAc/petroleum ether (1:3, v/v) as eluent, obtaining target compound 2e. White solid. 58% yield. Mp 232–235 °C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.73 (s, 1H), 8.65 (d, J = 0.9 Hz, 1H), 8.62 (br, 1H), 8.55 (d, J = 2.2 Hz, 1H), 7.82 (d, J = 0.9 Hz, 1H), 6.51 (dd, J = 2.7, 1.6 Hz, 1H), 2.29 (s, 2H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C9H9N5O (M+) 203.0807, found 203.0808.

    General Procedure for the Synthesis of 1-(6-(1H-Pyrazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl)-3-substituted Thioureas (2f–m)

    To a solution of 2d (1 mmol) in DMF (10 mL) was added NaH (60% dispersion in mineral oil, 48 mg, 1.2 mmol). The mixture was stirred for 5 min, and then corresponding isocyanate and isothiocyanates were added. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 0.5 h. Water was added, and the mixture was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 50 mL). The organic layer was separated and dried over Na2SO4. Removal of the solvents produced a residue which was purified using column chromatography, eluted with a mixture of MeOH/CH2Cl2, to afford corresponding target compounds in good yield.

    1-(6-(1H-Pyrazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl)-3-ethylurea (2f)

    White solid. 45% yield. Mp 195–197 °C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 9.75 (s, 1H), 8.64 (s, 1H), 8.62 (d, J = 2.7 Hz, 1H), 8.09 (s, 1H), 7.93 (d, J = 19.3 Hz, 1H), 7.49 (s, 1H), 6.62 (dd, J = 2.6, 1.6 Hz, 1H), 3.20 (m, J = 14.1, 7.1 Hz, 2H), 1.10 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C10H12N6O (M+) 232.1073, found 232.1074.

    1-(6-(1H-Pyrazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl)-3-ethylthiourea (2g)

    White solid. 40% yield. Mp 201–203 °C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.30 (t, J = 5.1 Hz, 1H), 11.09 (s, 1H), 8.73 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H), 8.63 (dd, J = 2.7, 0.5 Hz, 1H), 7.94 (d, J = 1.0 Hz, 1H), 7.64 (d, J = 0.9 Hz, 1H), 6.64 (dd, J = 2.7, 1.6 Hz, 1H), 3.79–3.53 (m, 2H), 1.28–1.06 (m, 3H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C10H12N6S (M+) 248.0844, found 248.0845.

    1-(6-(1H-Pyrazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl)-3-methylthiourea (2h)

    White solid. 63% yield. Mp 255–257 °C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.22 (d, J = 4.4 Hz, 1H), 11.16 (s, 1H), 8.72 (d, J = 0.9 Hz, 1H), 8.63 (d, J = 2.6 Hz, 1H), 7.94 (d, J = 1.1 Hz, 1H), 7.62 (d, J = 0.9 Hz, 1H), 6.64 (dd, J = 2.7, 1.6 Hz, 1H), 3.12 (d, J = 4.6 Hz, 3H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C9H10N6S (M+) 234.0688, found 234.0687.

    1-(6-(1H-Pyrazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl)-3-propylthiourea (2i)

    White solid. 74% yield. Mp 166–168 °C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.38 (s, 1H), 11.14 (s, 1H), 8.75 (s, 1H), 8.63 (s, 1H), 7.95 (s, 1H), 7.64 (s, 1H), 6.64 (s, 1H), 3.59 (dd, J = 12.7, 6.5 Hz, 2H), 1.77–1.55 (m, 2H), 0.96 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 3H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C11H14N6S (M+) 262.1001, found 262.1002.

    1-(6-(1H-Pyrazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl)-3-isopropylthiourea (2j)

    White solid. 76% yield. Mp 180–182 °C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.30 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H), 11.07 (s, 1H), 8.75 (d, J = 0.8 Hz, 1H), 8.66–8.50 (m, 1H), 7.94 (d, J = 1.0 Hz, 1H), 7.64 (d, J = 0.9 Hz, 1H), 6.64 (dd, J = 2.7, 1.6 Hz, 1H), 4.42 (m, J = 13.2, 6.6 Hz, 1H), 1.28 (d, J = 6.6 Hz, 6H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C11H14N6S (M+) 262.1001, found 262.1002.

    1-(6-(1H-Pyrazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl)-3-butylthiourea (2k)

    White solid. 68% yield. Mp 142–144 °C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO) δ 11.36 (t, J = 4.8 Hz, 1H), 11.13 (s, 1H), 8.75 (s, 1H), 8.63 (s, 1H), 7.95 (s, 1H), 7.63 (s, 1H), 6.64 (s, 1H), 3.62 (dd, J = 12.8, 6.5 Hz, 2H), 1.70–1.56 (m, 2H), 1.44–1.30 (m, 2H), 0.94 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 3H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C14H11ClN6S (M+) 330.0454, found 330.0452.

    General Procedure for the Synthesis of Different 1-Pyrimidin-3-ethylthioureas 3a–l

    To a solution of corresponding intermediates 7a–l (1 mmol) in DMF (8 mL) was added NaH (60% dispersion in mineral oil, 48 mg, 1.2 mmol). The solution was stirred for 5 min, and then ethyl isothiocyanate (87 mg, 1 mmol) was added. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 0.5 h. Water was added, and the mixture was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 50 mL). Organic layer was separated and dried over Na2SO4. Removal of the solvents produced a residue which was purified using column chromatography, eluted with a mixture of MeOH/CH2Cl2, to afford corresponding target compounds in good yield.

    1-(6-(1H-Pyrrol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl)-3-ethylthiourea (3a)

    White solid. 60% yield. Mp 226–229 °C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.25 (t, J = 5.0 Hz, 1H), 10.81 (s, 1H), 8.69 (s, 1H), 7.58–7.44 (m, 2H), 7.24 (d, J = 0.7 Hz, 1H), 6.54–6.26 (m, 2H), 3.77–3.54 (m, 2H), 1.22 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C11H13N5S (M+) 247.0892, found 247.0892.

    1-(6-(1H-Imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl)-3-ethylthiourea (3b)

    White solid. 54% yield. Mp 221–223 °C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.12 (d, J = 54.2 Hz, 1H), 10.98 (s, 1H), 8.77 (d, J = 0.8 Hz, 1H), 8.47 (d, J = 15.4 Hz, 1H), 7.75 (t, J = 1.4 Hz, 1H), 7.29 (t, J = 16.7 Hz, 1H), 7.23–6.97 (m, 1H), 3.76–3.56 (m, 1H), 1.31–1.08 (m, 1H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C10H12N6S (M+) 248.0844, found 248.0845.

    1-(6-(1H-1,2,3-Triazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl)-3-ethylthiourea (3c)

    White solid. 48% yield. Mp 252–254 °C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.26 (s, 1H), 11.22 (s, 1H), 9.17–8.77 (m, 2H), 8.06 (d, J = 1.0 Hz, 1H), 7.88 (s, 1H), 3.90–3.48 (m, 2H), 1.24 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C9H11N7S (M+) 249.0797, found 249.0796.

    1-(6-(1H-1,2,4-Triazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl)-3-ethylthiourea (3d)

    1-(6-(1H-Benzo[d]imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl)-3-ethylthiourea (3e)

    White solid. 46% yield. Mp 227–230 °C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.21 (s, 1H), 11.02 (s, 1H), 8.92 (s, 1H), 8.86 (s, 1H), 8.17 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 1H), 7.83 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.64 (s, 1H), 7.56–7.09 (m, 3H), 3.81–3.55 (m, 2H), 1.25 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C14H14N6S (M+) 298.1001, found 298.1002.

    1-Ethyl-3-(6-(pyrrolidin-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl)thiourea (3f)

    Yellow solid. 44% yield. Mp 194–196 °C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.57 (t, J = 5.0 Hz, 1H), 10.27 (s, 1H), 8.29 (d, J = 38.6 Hz, 1H), 6.06 (s, 1H), 3.73–3.53 (m, 2H), 3.53–2.99 (m, 4H), 1.96 (d, J = 24.4 Hz, 3H), 1.24–1.06 (m, 3H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C11H17N5S (M+) 251.1205, found 251.1204.

    1-Ethyl-3-(6-morpholinopyrimidin-4-yl)thiourea (3g)

    Yellow solid. 54% yield. Mp 168–170 °C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.46 (s, 1H), 10.32 (s, 1H), 8.31 (s, 1H), 6.35 (s, 1H), 3.71–3.64 (m, 3H), 3.64–3.53 (m, 2H), 3.52–3.42 (m, 3H), 1.19 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C11H17N5OS (M+) 267.1154, found 267.1155.

    1-Ethyl-3-(6-(4-methylpiperazin-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl)thiourea (3h)

    Yellow solid. 41% yield. Mp 169–172 °C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 11.52 (s, 1H), 8.33 (s, 1H), 8.27 (s, 1H), 5.79 (s, 1H), 3.82–3.71 (m, 2H), 3.71 (s, 4H), 2.55 (s, 3H), 2.40 (s, 3H), 1.32 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 3H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C12H20N6S (M+) 280.1470, found 280.1473.

    1-(6-(Benzylamino)pyrimidin-4-yl)-3-ethylthiourea (3i)

    Yellow solid. 51% yield. Mp 207–211 °C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.51 (t, J = 5.0 Hz, 1H), 10.33 (s, 1H), 8.19 (s, 1H), 8.00 (s, 1H), 7.59–6.98 (m, 5H), 6.11 (s, 1H), 4.46 (s, 2H), 3.70–3.40 (m, 2H), 1.16 (t, J = 7.1, 2.8 Hz, 3H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C14H17N5S (M+) 287.1205, found 287.1206.

    General Procedure for the Synthesis of Target Compounds 4a–e

    To a solution of corresponding intermediates 8a–e (1 mmol) in DMF (8 mL) was added NaH (60% dispersion in mineral oil, 48 mg, 1.2 mmol). The solution was stirred for 5 min, and then ethyl isothiocyanate (87 mg, 1 mmol) was added. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 0.5 h. Water was added, and the mixture was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 50 mL). Organic layer was separated and dried over Na2SO4. Removal of the solvents produced a residue which was purified using column chromatography, eluted with a mixture of MeOH/CH2Cl2, to afford corresponding target compounds 4a–e in good yield.

    1-(6-(1H-Imidazol-1-yl)-2-methylpyrimidin-4-yl)-3-ethylthiourea (4a)

    White solid. 60% yield. Mp 237–239 °C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.33 (s, 1H), 10.90 (s, 1H), 8.41 (s, 1H), 7.73 (s, 1H), 7.18 (s, 1H), 7.13 (s, 1H), 3.75–3.51 (m, 2H), 2.59 (s, 2H), 1.25 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C11H14N6S (M+) 262.1001, found 262.1002.

    1-(6-(1H-Imidazol-1-yl)-5-methylpyrimidin-4-yl)-3-ethylthiourea (4b)

    White solid. 58% yield. Mp 198–200 °C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.37 (s, 1H), 9.50 (s, 1H), 8.71 (s, 1H), 8.14 (s, 1H), 7.63 (s, 1H), 7.14 (s, 1H), 3.79–3.48 (m, 2H), 2.26 (s, 3H), 1.23 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C11H14N6S (M+) 262.1001, found 262.1002.

    1-(2-(1H-Imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl)-3-ethylthiourea (4c)

    White solid. 65% yield. Mp 242–245 °C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.10 (s, 1H), 10.45 (s, 1H), 8.55 (d, J = 5.8 Hz, 1H), 8.49 (s, 1H), 7.84 (s, 1H), 7.17 (s, 1H), 7.09 (d, J = 5.8 Hz, 1H), 3.77–3.50 (m, 2H), 1.28 (t, 3H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C10H12N6S (M+) 248.0844, found 248.0845.

    1-(4-(1H-Imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-2-yl)-3-ethylthiourea (4d)

    White solid. 68% yield. Mp 244–246 °C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.90 (d, J = 71.8 Hz, 1H), 10.72 (s, 1H), 8.72 (d, J = 5.6 Hz, 1H), 8.66 (s, 1H), 8.01 (s, 1H), 7.55 (d, J = 5.7 Hz, 1H), 7.20 (s, 1H), 3.81–3.54 (m, 2H), 1.22 (t, J = 19.2, 12.1 Hz, 3H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C10H12N6S (M+) 248.0844, found 248.0845.

    1-(4-(1H-Imidazol-1-yl)-6,7-dihydro-5H-cyclopenta[d]pyrimidin-2-yl)-3-ethylthiourea (4e)

    White solid. 63% yield. Mp 285–286 °C. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.91 (s, 1H), 10.60 (s, 1H), 8.45 (s, 1H), 7.89 (s, 1H), 7.21 (s, 1H), 3.73–3.54 (m, 2H), 3.22–3.09 (m, 2H), 3.05–2.88 (m, 2H), 2.22–2.06 (m, 2H), 1.24 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C13H16N6S (M+) 288.1157, found 288.1158.

    General Procedure for the Synthesis of 1-(6-(1H-Imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl)-3-ethylthioureas 5a–j

    To a solution of corresponding intermediates 9a–j (1 mmol) in DMF (8 mL) was added NaH (60% dispersion in mineral oil, 48 mg, 1.2 mmol). The solution was stirred for 5 min, and then ethyl isothiocyanate (87 mg, 1 mmol) was added. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 0.5 h. Water was added, and the mixture was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 50 mL). Organic layer was separated and dried over Na2SO4. Removal of the solvents produced a residue which was purified using column chromatography, eluted with a mixture of MeOH/CH2Cl2, to afford corresponding target compounds 5a–j in good yields.

    1-Ethyl-3-(6-(2-methyl-1H-imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl)thiourea (5a)

    White solid. 60% yield. Mp 201–204 °C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.29–11.04 (m, 1H), 10.99 (s, 1H), 8.80 (s, 1H), 7.60 (d, J = 1.5 Hz, 1H), 7.33 (s, 1H), 6.94 (t, J = 17.7 Hz, 1H), 3.77–3.55 (m, 2H), 2.58 (s, 3H), 1.26–1.17 (m, 4H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C11H14N6S (M+) 262.1001, found 262.1002.

    1-Ethyl-3-(6-(4-(hydroxymethyl)-1H-imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl)thiourea (5k)

    To a solution of compound 5i (276 mg, 1 mmol) in MeOH/CH2Cl2 = 1:1 (5:5 mL) was added NaBH4 (45.4 mg, 1.2 mmol), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 5 h, and the solvent was evaporated to dryness under reduced pressure. The residue was purified on a silica gel column using mixtures of MeOH/CH2Cl2 (1:20, v/v) as eluent, obtaining the target compound 5k. White solid, 50% yield. Mp 238–240 °C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.19 (t, J = 5.0 Hz, 1H), 10.93 (s, 1H), 8.75 (s, 1H), 8.39 (s, 1H), 7.52 (s, 1H), 7.27 (s, 1H), 5.13 (t, J = 5.7 Hz, 1H), 4.43 (d, J = 5.6 Hz, 2H), 3.75–3.50 (m, 2H), 1.31–1.14 (m, 3H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C11H14N6OS (M+) 278.0950, found 287.0952.

    General Procedure for the Synthesis of 1-(6-(4-(Aminomethyl)-1H-imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl)-3-ethylthioureas 5l–x

    To a solution of compound 5i (138 mg, 0.5 mmol) in MeOH/DCE = 1:1 was added corresponding alicyclic amines (1 mmol), AcOH (1 mmol), and NaBH3(CN) (62.8 mg, 1 mmol) in sequence. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 12 h, and solvent was evaporated to dryness under reduced pressure. The residue was purified on a silica gel column using mixtures of MeOH/CH2Cl2 as eluent, obtaining the target compounds 5l–x.

    1-Ethyl-3-(6-(4-((methylamino)methyl)-1H-imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl)thiourea (5l)

    Reagents used were compound 5i (138 mg, 0.5 mmol), methylamine (1 mmol, 2 M in THF), AcOH (60 mg, 1 mmol), and NaBH3(CN) (62.8 mg, 1 mmol). Purification involved the use of MeOH/CH2Cl2 (1:5, v/v) as eluent. Compound 5l: yellow solid. 40% yield. Mp 114–117 °C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.19 (s, 1H), 8.85–8.69 (m, 1H), 8.59–8.36 (m, 1H), 7.66 (s, 1H), 7.33–7.22 (m, 1H), 3.77 (s, 2H), 3.70–3.57 (m, 3H), 2.40 (s, 3H), 1.22 (t, J = 7.1 Hz, 3H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C12H17N7S (M+) 291.1266, found 291.1267.

    1-Ethyl-3-(6-(4-((ethylamino)methyl)-1H-imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl)thiourea (5m)

    Reagents used were compound 5i (138 mg, 0.5 mmol), ethylamine (1 mmol, 2 M in THF), AcOH (60 mg, 1 mmol), and NaBH3(CN) (62.8 mg, 1 mmol). Purification involved the use of MeOH/CH2Cl2 (1:10, v/v) as eluent. Compound 5m: yellow solid. 55% yield. Mp 105–108 °C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.20 (t, J = 5.0 Hz, 1H), 8.77 (d, J = 15.5 Hz, 1H), 8.53–8.32 (m, 1H), 7.59 (s, 1H), 7.39–7.23 (m, 1H), 3.71 (s, 2H), 3.68–3.59 (m, 3H), 2.70–2.58 (m, 2H), 1.23 (t, J = 7.1 Hz, 3H), 1.13–1.02 (m, 3H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C13H19N7S (M+) 305.1423, found 305.1424.

    1-(6-(4-((Cyclohexylamino)methyl)-1H-imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl)-3-ethylthiourea (5n)

HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C17H25N7S (M+) 359.1892, found 359.1893.

    1-Ethyl-3-(6-(4-(morpholinomethyl)-1H-imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl)thiourea (5w)

    Reagents used were compound 5i (138 mg, 0.5 mmol), morpholine (87 μL, 1 mmol), AcOH (60 mg, 1 mmol), and NaBH3(CN) (62.8 mg, 1 mmol). Purification involved the use of MeOH/CH2Cl2 (1:10, v/v) as eluent. Compound 5w: white solid. 60% yield. Mp 188–190 °C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 11.24 (s, 1H), 9.46 (s, 1H), 8.65 (s, 1H), 8.42 (s, 1H), 7.69 (s, 1H), 6.97 (s, 1H), 3.91–3.62 (m, 8H), 2.75 (s, 4H), 1.37 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 3H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C15H21N7OS (M+) 347.1528, found 347.1515.

    1-Ethyl-3-(6-(4-((4-methylpiperazin-1-yl)methyl)-1H-imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-yl)thiourea (5x)

    Reagents used were compound 5i (138 mg, 0.5 mmol), 1-methylpiperazine (111 μL, 1 mmol), AcOH (60 mg, 1 mmol), and NaBH3(CN) (62.8 mg, 1 mmol). Purification involved the use of MeOH/CH2Cl2 (1:8, v/v) as eluent. Compound 5l: white solid. 48% yield. Mp 178–179 °C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.19 (t, J = 5.3 Hz, 1H), 10.94 (s, 1H), 8.75 (s, 1H), 8.38 (s, 1H), 7.55 (s, 1H), 7.29 (s, 1H), 3.75–3.56 (m, 2H), 3.46 (s, 2H), 3.41–3.21 (m, 4H), 2.48–2.30 (m, 4H), 2.21 (s, 3H), 1.23 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H). HRMS (EI) m/z calcd C16H24N8S (M+) 360.1845, found 360.1847.

    4-Chloro-6-(1H-pyrazol-1-yl)pyrimidine (6)

    A mixture of pyrazole (272 mg, 4 mmol), 4,6-dichloropyrimidine (596 mg, 4 mmol), and Cs2CO3 (1434 mg, 4.4 mmol) was stirred in DMF (10 mL) for 12 h at room temperature. Water (60 mL) was added. The mixture was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 60 mL). The organic layer was separated and dried over Na2SO4. Removal of the solvents produced a residue which was purified using column chromatography, eluted with a mixture of EtOAc/petroleum ether (1:50, v/v), to afford 6 (427 mg, 60%) as a white solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.97 (d, J = 0.9 Hz, 1H), 8.76–8.68 (m, 1H), 8.01 (d, J = 1.1 Hz, 1H), 7.98 (d, J = 0.9 Hz, 1H), 6.71 (dd, J = 2.7, 1.6 Hz, 1H).

    6-(1H-Pyrrol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-amine (7a)

    To a solution of pyrrole (70 μL, 1 mmol) in DMF was added NaH (60% dispersion in mineral oil, 60 mg, 1.5 mmol). The mixture was stirred for 5 min, and then 4-amino-6-chloropyrimidine (130 mg, 1 mmol) was added. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2 h, then water was added. The mixture was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 50 mL), the organic layer was separated and dried over Na2SO4. Removal of the solvents produced a residue which was purified using column chromatography, eluted with a mixture of MeOH/CH2Cl2, obtaining target compound 7a. Yellow solid, 15% yield. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.27 (s, 1H), 7.54 (s, 2H), 7.00 (s, 2H), 6.48 (s, 1H), 6.30 (s, 2H).

    General Procedure for the Synthesis of 6-Substituted Pyrimidin-4-amines (7b–i)

    A mixture of 4-amino-6-chloropyrimidine (1.30 g, 10 mmol), corresponding nitrogen heterocyclic compounds or alicyclic amine (11 mmol), and Cs2CO3 (3.91 g, 12 mmol) was stirred in DMF (20 mL) for 12–24 h at 100–120 °C. Water (100 mL) was added. The mixture was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 100 mL). The organic layer was separated and dried over Na2SO4. Removal of the solvents produced a residue which was purified using column chromatography, eluted with a mixture of MeOH/CH2Cl2, to afford the intermediates 7b–i.

    6-(1H-Imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-amine (7b)

    White solid. 45% yield. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.48–8.43 (m, 1H), 8.33 (d, J = 0.8 Hz, 1H), 7.82 (t, J = 1.4 Hz, 1H), 7.20 (s, 2H), 7.15–7.08 (m, 1H), 6.57 (d, J = 1.0 Hz, 1H).

    6-(1H-1,2,3-Triazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-amine (7c)

    White solid. 40% yield. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.78 (d, J = 1.1 Hz, 1H), 8.42 (s, 1H), 7.99 (d, J = 1.1 Hz, 1H), 7.45 (s, 2H), 7.09 (d, J = 0.7 Hz, 1H).

    6-(1H-1,2,4-Triazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-amine (7d)

    White solid. 42% yield. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 9.32 (s, 1H), 8.37 (t, J = 5.1 Hz, 4H), 8.32 (s, 4H), 7.39 (s, 8H), 6.84 (d, J = 0.9 Hz, 5H).

    6-(1H-Benzo[d]imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-amine (7e)

    White solid. 35% yield. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.89 (s, 1H), 8.45 (d, J = 0.7 Hz, 1H), 8.20 (t, J = 7.7 Hz, 1H), 7.87–7.69 (m, 1H), 7.47–7.30 (m, 2H), 7.24 (s, 2H), 6.82 (d, J = 0.9 Hz, 1H).

    6-(Pyrrolidin-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-amine (7f)

    White solid. 25% yield. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.17 (s, 1H), 7.27 (s, 1H), 5.33 (d, J = 18.2 Hz, 1H), 4.63 (s, 2H), 3.42 (s, 4H), 1.99 (s, 4H).

    6-Morpholinopyrimidin-4-amine (7g)

    White solid. 50% yield. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.17 (d, J = 16.6 Hz, 1H), 7.27 (s, 1H), 5.53 (d, J = 35.7 Hz, 1H), 4.78 (s, 2H), 3.89–3.69 (m, 4H), 3.65–3.40 (m, 4H).

    6-(4-Methylpiperazin-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-amine (7h)

    White solid. 55% yield. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.19 (s, 1H), 7.27 (s, 1H), 5.58 (s, 1H), 4.62 (s, 2H), 3.61 (dd, J = 16.5, 11.5 Hz, 4H), 2.59–2.44 (m, 4H), 2.35 (s, 3H).

    N4-Benzylpyrimidine-4,6-diamine (7i)

    White solid. 15% yield. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.12 (s, 1H), 7.33 (m, J = 14.5, 7.3 Hz, 5H), 5.37 (s, 1H), 5.23 (br, 1H), 4.56 (br, 2H), 4.43 (d, J = 5.8 Hz, 2H).

    General Procedure for the Synthesis of Intermediates 9a–j

    A mixture of 4-amino-6-chloropyrimidine (1.30 g, 10 mmol), corresponding substituted imidazoles (11 mmol), and Cs2CO3 (3.91 g, 12 mmol) was stirred in DMF (20 mL) for 12–24 h at 100–120 °C. Water (100 mL) was added. The mixture was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 100 mL). The organic layer was separated and dried over Na2SO4. Removal of the solvents produced a residue which was purified using column chromatography, eluted with a mixture of MeOH/CH2Cl2, to afford the intermediates 9a–j.

    6-(2-Methyl-1H-imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-amine (9a)

    Yellow solid. 55% yield. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.36 (d, J = 0.7 Hz, 1H), 7.51 (d, J = 1.5 Hz, 1H), 7.20 (s, 2H), 6.90 (d, J = 1.5 Hz, 1H), 6.48 (d, J = 0.9 Hz, 1H), 2.52 (d, J = 2.6 Hz, 3H).

    6-(2-Ethyl-1H-imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-amine (9b)

    Yellow solid. 50% yield. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.35 (t, J = 6.6 Hz, 1H), 7.48 (d, J = 1.5 Hz, 1H), 7.21 (s, 2H), 6.92 (d, J = 1.5 Hz, 1H), 6.46 (t, J = 3.3 Hz, 1H), 2.92 (q, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 1.35–1.06 (m, 3H).

    6-(4-Methyl-1H-imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-amine (9c)

    Yellow solid. 50% yield. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.32 (d, J = 1.1 Hz, 1H), 8.29 (s, 1H), 7.50 (s, 1H), 7.14 (s, 2H), 6.48 (d, J = 0.8 Hz, 1H), 2.16 (s, 3H).

    6-(4-Chloro-1H-imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-amine (9d)

    Yellow solid. 48% yield. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.47 (dd, J = 19.5, 1.5 Hz, 1H), 8.33 (d, J = 0.6 Hz, 1H), 7.98 (d, J = 1.6 Hz, 1H), 7.29 (s, 2H), 6.57 (d, J = 0.9 Hz, 1H).

    6-(4-Bromo-1H-imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-amine (9e)

    Yellow solid. 40% yield. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.45 (d, J = 1.4 Hz, 1H), 8.33 (s, 1H), 8.03 (d, J = 1.4 Hz, 1H), 7.28 (s, 2H), 6.58 (s, 1H).

    6-(4-Iodo-1H-imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-amine (9f)

    Yellow solid. 41% yield. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.40 (d, J = 1.1 Hz, 1H), 8.32 (s, 1H), 8.05 (d, J = 1.1 Hz, 1H), 7.25 (s, 2H), 6.56 (s, 1H).

    6-(4-(Trifluoromethyl)-1H-imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-amine (9g)

    Yellow solid. 30% yield. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.67 (d, J = 19.8 Hz, 1H), 8.52 (s, 1H), 8.38 (d, J = 11.9 Hz, 1H), 7.34 (s, 2H), 6.71 (s, 1H).

    6-(4-Nitro-1H-imidazol-1-yl)pyrimidin-4-amine (9h)

    Yellow solid. 10% yield. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.99 (d, J = 1.4 Hz, 1H), 8.63 (d, J = 1.4 Hz, 1H), 8.40 (s, 1H), 8.32 (d, J = 1.0 Hz, 1H), 7.85 (s, 1H), 7.43 (s, 2H), 6.80 (s, 1H).

    1-(6-Aminopyrimidin-4-yl)-1H-imidazole-4-carbaldehyde (9i)

    Yellow solid. 30% yield. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 9.86 (d, J = 19.8 Hz, 1H), 8.71 (s, 1H), 8.64 (s, 1H), 8.38 (s, 1H), 7.35 (s, 2H), 6.72 (s, 1H).

    Methyl 1-(6-Aminopyrimidin-4-yl)-1H-imidazole-4-carboxylate (9j)

    Yellow solid. 8% yield. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.59 (d, J = 28.8 Hz, 1H), 8.49 (d, J = 1.0 Hz, 1H), 8.38 (d, J = 16.0 Hz, 1H), 7.33 (d, J = 28.6 Hz, 2H), 6.73 (s, 1H), 3.81 (d, J = 11.8 Hz, 2H).

    Inhibition of ChE

    The ChE assay was performed using the method of Ellman et al. with slight modification.(46) The rat cortex was homogenized in cold 75 mM sodium phosphate buffer (pH 7.4) as the AChE source, and the rat serum was collected as the BuChE source. The assay solution consisted of 50 μL of 0.1 M phosphate buffer, 50 μL of 0.2% 5,5′-dithiobis (2-nitrobenzoic acid) (DTNB, Sigma), 109 or 99 μL of deionized water, 10 μL of rat cortex homogenate or 20 μL of rat serum, and 30 μL of 2 mM acetylthiocholine iodide (Sigma) or 40 μL of 2 mM butyrylthiocholine (Sigma) as the substrate of the AChE or BuChE enzymatic reaction, respectively. An appropriate concentration of compound (1 nM to 10 mM; 1 μL) and the assay solution were mixed and then incubated for 20 min at room temperature. The production of the yellow anion of 5-thio-2-nitrobenzoic acid was measured with a microplate reader (DTX 880, Beckman Coulter) at 450 nm. The inhibition percentage caused by the presence of test compound was calculated, and the IC50 was defined as the concentration of the compound that reduced 50% of the enzymatic activity without inhibitor.

    Oxygen Radical Absorbance Capacity (ORAC-FL) Assay

    The tested compound and fluorescein (FL) stock solution were diluted with 75 mM phosphate buffer (pH 7.4) to 20 μM and 0.117 μM, respectively. A solution of (±)-6-hydroxy-2,5,7,8-tetramethylchroman-2-carboxylic acid (Trolox) was diluted with the same buffer to 100, 80, 60, 50, 40, 20, and 10 μM. A solution of 2,2′-azobis(amidinopropane) dihydrochloride (AAPH) was prepared before the experiment by dissolving 108.4 mg of AAPH in 10 mL of 75 mM phosphate buffer (pH 7.4) to a concentration of 40 mM. The mixture of the tested compounds (20 μL) and FL (120 μL; 70 nM, final concentration) was preincubated for 10 min at 37 °C, and then 60 μL of the AAPH solution was added. The fluorescence was recorded by Molecular Devices every minute for 180 min (SpectraMax i3; excitation, 485 nm; emission, 520 nm). A blank using phosphate buffer instead of the tested compounds was also analyzed. All reaction mixtures were prepared in triplicate, and at least three independent runs were performed for each sample. The antioxidant curves (fluorescence versus time) were normalized to the curve of the blank. The area under the fluorescence decay curve (AUC) was calculated using the following equation:where f0 is the initial fluorescence reading at 0 min and fi is the fluorescence reading at time i. The net AUC was calculated by the expression AUCsample – AUCblank. Regression equations between the net AUC and Trolox concentrations were calculated. The ORAC-FL values for each sample were calculated using the standard curve, which gives the ORAC-FL value of the tested compounds expressed as Trolox equivalents.

    Metal-Chelating Study

    The chelating studies were performed with a UV–vis spectrophotometer at wavelengths ranging from 200 to 500 nm. The absorption spectra of each compound (5r, 5t, 5y, 40 μM, final concentration) alone or in the presence of CuCl2, FeSO4, FeCl3, or ZnCl2 (20 μM, final concentration) for 1 h in buffer (20 mM HEPES, 150 mM NaCl, pH 7.4) were recorded at room temperature. Due to poor water solubility, the reference CQ (40 μM, final concentration) was tested alone or in the presence of CuCl2, FeSO4, FeCl3, or ZnCl2 (20 μM, final concentration) in ethanol.

    Dot Blot Assay

    Aβ1–42 (Sigma, CA, U.S.) was dissolved in ammonium hydroxide (1% v/v) to give a stock solution (2000 μM), which was aliquoted into small samples and stored at −80 °C. For the experiments, the Aβ1–42 stock solution was diluted in 20 μM HEPES (pH 6.6) with 150 μM NaCl. The mixture of the peptide (25 μM, final concentration) with or without Cu(II) (25 μM, final concentration) and the test compound (50 μM, final concentration) was incubated at 37 °C for 24 h.
    For the dot immunoblot assay, each Aβ sample was spotted (5 μL) on nitrocellulose membranes (GE Healthcare). Afterward, the membranes were blocked by 5% nonfat milk for 1 h and probed with A11 (Millipore) or 6E10 (Convance) antibodies at 4 °C overnight. The blots were washed with TBST and incubated with suitable horseradish peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibodies at room temperature for 1 h. Images were acquired by an image system (Tanon) and were analyzed using ImageJ software.

    TEM Assay(69, 70)

    For the inhibition of the Cu(II)-induced Aβ1–42 aggregation experiment, the preparation of the sample was the same as the dot blot assay. Aliquots (10 μL) of the samples were placed on a carbon-coated copper grid for 20 min. Each grid was stained with phosphotungstic acid (2%, 10 μL) for 1 min. After draining the excess staining solution, the specimen was transferred for imaging by transmission electron microscopy (JEM-1400). All compounds were solubilized in the buffer used for the experiment.

    Ascorbate

    All of the solutions, except CuSO4 (dissolved in water and diluted in PBS) and 5r and 5t (dissolved in methanol and diluted in PBS), were mixed and diluted in a PBS buffer (20 mM, containing NaCl 100 mM, pH 7.4) with a final sample volume of 200 μL. Each experiment was performed in triplicate. Hydroxyl radical production was measured as the conversion of CCA into 7-hydroxy-CCA by Molecular Devices at 37 °C (SpectraMax i3; excitation, 395 nm; emission, 450 nm). The general order of addition was as follows: ligand [15 μM] or PBS, Cu(II) [5 μM], deferoxamine [1 μM], CCA [50 μM], and then ascorbate [150 μM]. All of the test solutions contained 0.1% methanol.

    Cell Viability Assay

    SH-SY5Y human neuroblastoma cells were cultured in Dulbecco’s modified Eagle medium (DMEM)/F12 medium (GIBCO), containing 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS, GIBCO). Cells were seeded into 96-well plates (Corning) at a density of 3 × 104 cells per well for the following experiments. For neurotoxicity test, cells were treated with compounds at 10 μM, 30 μM, 100 μM for 24 h. Cell viability was measured by 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide (MTT, Sangon Biotech, China) analysis. Briefly, 10 μL of MTT (5 mg/mL) was added into each well and incubated at 37 °C for 4 h. The production of MTT formazan was determined by measuring the absorbance at 490 nm. The cell viability was calculated and presented by the percentage of vehicle-treated group.
    For neuroprotection of compounds 5r and 5t on Cu2+-induced Aβ1–42 neurotoxic model, Aβ samples, which has the same preparation condition as dot blot assay, were added into the cell cultures at a concentration of 1 μM for 24 h. Then the cell viability was measured by MTT assay and normalized by vehicle group.

    In Vitro Blood–Brain Barrier Permeation Assay

    Brain penetration of compounds was evaluated using a parallel artificial membrane permeation assay (PAMPA), in a similar manner as described by Di et al. Commercial drugs were purchased from Sigma and Alfa Aesar. The porcine brain lipid (PBL) was obtained from Avanti Polar Lipids. The donor microplate (PVDF membrane, pore size 0.45 mm) and the acceptor microplate were both from Millipore. The 96-well UV plate was from Corning Incorporated. The acceptor 96-well microplate was filled with 300 μL of PBS/EtOH (7:3), and the filter membrane was impregnated with 4 μL of PBL in dodecane (20 mg mL–1). Compounds were dissolved in DMSO at 5 mg mL–1 and diluted 50-fold in PBS/EtOH (7:3) to get the concentration of 100 μg mL–1, then 200 μL was added to the donor wells. The acceptor filter plate was carefully placed on the donor plate to form a sandwich, which was left undisturbed for 10 h at 25 °C. After incubation, the donor plate was carefully removed and the concentration of compounds in the acceptor wells was determined using a UV plate reader (Flexstation 3). Each sample was analyzed at five wavelengths, in four wells, in at least three independent runs, and the results are given as the mean ± standard deviation. Pe was calculated using the following equation.where Vd is the volume in the donor well, Va is the volume in the acceptor well, A is the filter area, t is the permeation time, [drug]acceptor is the absorbance of the compound in the acceptor well, and [drug]equilibrium is the theoretical equilibrium absorbance.
    In the experiment, 13 quality control standards of known BBB permeability were included to validate the analysis set (Table S3, Supporting Information). A plot of the experimental data versus reference values gave a strong linear correlation, Pe (exp) = 1.4574Pe (lit.) – 1.0773 (R2 = 0.9427) (Figure S5, Supporting Information). From this equation and the limit established by Di et al. for blood–brain barrier permeation, we concluded that compounds with permeability greater than 4.7 × 10–6 cm/s could cross the blood–brain barrier (Table S4, Supporting Information).

    Water Solubility Assay

    The water solubility of compounds 5t, 5r, 5s, 5t·HCl, 5r·HCl, and 5ts·HCl was determined by HPLC (Agilent 1100 with quaternary pump, diode array detector). Stock solutions (1 mg/mL) of sample were prepared in methanol. Then, samples of 10 μL of dilute solutions with concentrations of 1, 0.5, 0.2, 0.1, 0.05, 0.002, 0.001, and 0.0005 mg/mL were injected into the HPLC system to assess linearity. Calibration curves were plotted as the peak area versus concentration of sample. To prepare the saturated water solution, 10 mg of compound was added to a 5 mL centrifuge tube, and 1 mL of pure water was pipetted into the tube. If the solution was unsaturated and remained clear and transparent, additional test compound was added. After stirring for 24 h, the solution was filtered with a syringe filter, and 10 μL was injected into the HPLC system. Water solubility was calculated by comparing the peak area of the tested compound to the calibration curves.

    Cognitive Ability Test

    Imprinting control region (ICR) mice (18–20 g) were obtained from the Shanghai Laboratory Animal Center, Chinese Academy of Sciences. The animal handling and experiment protocols were approved by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee of the Shanghai Institute of Materia Medica.
    A passageway water maze (80 cm × 50 cm × 20 cm) was used to evaluate the cognition and memory of mice. The mice were placed into the water maze, with their nose toward the wall of the starting point, and were trained to find the final point. Each mouse received 2 training sessions daily for 4 days. Trained mice were randomly assigned to subgroups (N = 17). Compounds (200 mg/kg) were administered (ig) 1 h before and scopolamine was injected (ip) 20 min before the behavior test. The escape latency and number of errors were recorded. Hup A was administered as a positive control.

    Measuring 5r in Plasma and Brain Samples

    LC–MS/MS was applied to determine the ability of 5r to penetrate the blood–brain barrier (BBB) in vivo. Compound 5r·HCl was administered to mice by oral gavage at 200 mg/kg, and the plasma, cortex, hippocampus were collected from three animals after 1 h. For the preparation of plasma samples, 25 μL of plasma was mixed with 25 μL of methanol, 25 μL of internal standard solution, and 75 μL of acetonitrile and centrifuged at 14 400 rpm for 5 min. The resulting supernatant was injected into the LC–MS/MS. For brain samples, the tissue was sonicated in 4× mass of saline to obtain the brain homogenate. A 50 μL volume of methanol, 50 μL of internal standard solutionn and 50 μL of acetonitrile were added to 50 μL of brain homogenate to precipitate the proteins, and the solution was subjected to the above-described extraction procedure. The calibration standards were prepared in blank samples on the day of analysis by adding the appropriate volume of diluted compound 5r·HCl solution.

    Statistical Analysis

    Data were analyzed by one-way ANOVA followed by Dunnett’s test for multiple comparisons or by Student’s t test for single comparison. A P value <0.05 was considered significant.

    Abbreviations Used

    AChE

    acetylcholinesterase

    BBB

    blood–brain barrier

    AD

    Alzheimer’s disease

    MTDL

    multitarget-directed ligand

    ACh

    acetylcholine

    AChEI

    AChE inhibitor

    Aβ

    β-amyloid protein

    CNS

    central nervous system

    ROS

    reactive oxygen species

    MW

    molecular weight

    BuChE

    butyrylcholinesterase

    Hup A

    huperzine A

    ORAC

    free oxygen radical absorbance capacity

    CQ

    clioquinol

    TEM

    transmission electron microscopy

    ThT

    thioflavine T

    EGCG

    epigallocatechin gallate

    CCA

    coumarin-3-carboxylic acid

    EDTA

    ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid

    MTT

    3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide

    Don

    donepezil

    PAMPA

    parallel artificial membrane permeation assay

    tPSA

    topological polar surface area

    mp

    melting point

    clogP

    calculated logarithm of the octanol–water partition coefficient

    Scop

    scopolamine

    TLC

    thin-layer chromatography

    AAPH

    2,2′-azobis-(amidinopropane)dihydrochloride

    LC–MS/MS

    liquid chromatography tandem mass spectrometry

    HEPES

    2-[4-(2-hydroxyethyl)piperazin-1-yl]ethanesulfonic acid

    PBS

    phosphate buffer salt
